div.div: Use of arrow keys when focused on the Google language option field will translate site content on the fly. Use your enter key to review all options and choose your selection before applying.

span.a: You are currently on this page - Coronavirus (COVID-19) Information

td.p: Today, Governor Evers has announced that all schools will be closed through the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. Additionally, the Governor's Safer-At-Home order has been extended through Tuesday, May 26.
The Neenah Joint School District Digital Learning Days will continue through the last regularly-scheduled school day on June 4.

We realize this will be challenging for all of our students not to have closure to the school year with their friends and teachers. However, we hope that our classes will still be able to connect in creative ways virtually to bring this school year to a proper ending. We will share more details related to the month of May in the near future.

For our seniors, this is an especially difficult ending and our hearts go out to you. Our hope is to have a graduation ceremony in some form, even if it is delayed into the summer. Details regarding graduation and other upcoming events during May will be provided in the near future.

We hope everyone is continuing to stay safe. We also thank our staff, students and parents for your continued dedication to learning in a virtual environment. We are also thankful for our continued partnerships with Kobussen and Chartwells as we serve lunches throughout the week. Together, we will get through this.

p.br:
St Joseph's Food Pantry is located at 1465 Opportunity Way Menasha
(920)734-9461. As long as they remain open they are able to serve families even if they are not signed up. If they need to close they will do a drive through service.

td.p: The Menasha Boys and Girls Club is serving supper bags to families that need assistance. M-F 4:30 pm to 5:30 pm. Click here for more information

p.a: Click here for more food options in the Fox Valley

p.br:
Hope Clinic serves medical needs for uninsured families. At this time, if you are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 they ask that you call the Winnebago County Health Department.
Neenah office: 729-2945
Oshkosh office: 232-3000

td.p: If you have insurance you are encouraged to contact your primary care provider.

p.br: TEXT HOPELINE: We all need hope, help, and support at points in our life free of negative stigma or judgment. Text HOPELINE to 741741 — from anywhere, anytime, about any type of mental health or AODA concern.

td.p: Winnebago County Crisis (920) 233-7707. Parents can call if they are concerned about themselves or their child feeling suicidal. Crisis will assess and come up with a safety plan.
You can also call 911 if you are concerned about yourself or someone else experiencing suicidal thoughts.
If you are currently receiving mental health services, please call to see how appointments will be handled. This can change daily.
Catalpa Health offers tele-counseling. Click here for more information.

p.br: For those with preteens, teens or young adults in the home, your best-laid plans for supporting their healthy development can be thrown off course or strengthened during this time. What can parents and other caregivers do to reduce the potential that children who are understandably feeling frustrated, anxious, bored, depressed or isolated might engage in substance use as a distraction or to self-medicate? Click here to learn more.
Winnebago County Access Child Abuse/Neglect: (920) 236-4615. If you are concerned about a child being abused or neglected you can call and make an anonymous report to Winnebago County.

Spectrum is offering free internet services to students in need.
Call 1-844-488-8395.

The pandemic has left many Wisconsin households with less income or no paycheck at all. On March 27, 2020, Wisconsin issued Emergency Order #15 Temporary Ban on Evictions and Foreclosures that can be found on this link. This order prevents landlords from starting eviction actions or serving any eviction notices for 60-days. This temporary moratorium only applies to evictions related to failure to pay rent. Evictions may still be served for other valid reasons not related to missed rent payments.

td.div: The 60-day freeze on evictions does not mean that tenants get two months of free rent. Each landlord or rental management company will determine how to handle this situation, keeping in mind that delayed rent payments will likely be added onto future rent payments. Households who still have money coming in can certainly continue to make on-time monthly rent payments. If you know you will not be able to pay your rent, it’s best to contact your landlord before you miss a payment so they know you are keeping track and aware of the situation. Check out the Extension publication on Dealing with a Drop in Income for steps to take in prioritizing bills and contacting your landlord about a payment plan.

p.br: The U.S. Department of Labor Disaster Unemployment Assistance provides benefits to individuals who are unemployed due to a major disaster. To find out if you qualify contact 1-877-872-5627.

div.p: United Way has a COVID-19 Economic Relief Fund. They can help with bills and rent and food. Call 1-866-211-9966.
The United Way also offers resources by calling 2-1-1
The Department of Workforce Development offers information about unemployment and job opportunities
Leaven is not open to the public to come in the building but they can call for assistance. 738-9635.

p.br: Pillars Homeless Shelter-no restriction yet on the number of people they can service. There is a long waiting list and some openings coming soon but they will be taking people off the list for those openings. The best thing to do is call to be added to the list (920) 832-1479.

div.p: Christine Anne Domestic Abuse Shelter-will do a case by case basis. Please call them at (920)235-5998.

p.br: The Department of Children and Families have launched two tools to help connect essential workforce families to local, safe child care. You can go to their website for more information

div.p: Once there, click on the “Find Child Care” section at the bottom of the page.
On that site there is a link to request childcare information Request Child care.
Free lunches and breakfasts will be available for anyone 18 and under beginning Wednesday, March 18 at 97 different locations throughout the District.

p.a: Click here for a full schedule and more information

div.p:
Send an e-mail to:
njsdtech@neenah.k12.wi.us
if you are having issues with your iPad or Chromebook during the Digital Learning Days.

Spectrum cable is offering free wi-fi for families during this time period by calling 1-844-488-8398. This is strictly an offer promoted by Spectrum and the District has no involvement in the offer. Installation and equipment is also free.
